roleset.name: move from one place to another, moving from one place to another (not means of transportation/vehicle itself)
roleset.note: TRANSPORT-V NOTES: Frames file for 'transport' based on sentences in wsj. Verbnet entry 11.1-1. (from transport.01-v predicate notes)
TRANSPORT-N NOTES: Added by Julia based on transport-v.01. Corresponds to VNcls send-11.1. (from transport.01-n)

roles.note: If you want to make the rel your Arg1, you're not looking at an eventive usage (from transportation.01-n)

example.name: just transitive
example.text: Consolidated Rail Corp. said it would spend more than $30 million on [1,000 enclosed railcars]-1 for *trace*-1 transporting autos.

example.name: with destination
example.text: But [Brooks]-2 declined, [*trace*-2]-1 figuring that *trace*-1 transporting the mucked up money to Washington would cost the company thousands more.

example.name: with source and destination
example.text: Foothills Pipe Lines Ltd. filed an application with Canadian regulators to build [a 4.4 billion Canadian dollar (US$ 3.74 billion) pipeline]-1 *trace*-1 to transport natural gas from Canada's Arctic to U.S. markets beginning in...

example.name: source and destination in one word = path= arg4
example.text: 56 - year - old Forry Drake has been charged with interstate transport of a minor .

example.name: another path, where source and destination are together
example.text: The " little three links " - direct mail , transport , and commerce between the ROC islands of Kinmen and Matsu on the one side and the PRC on the other - were formally opened on January 2 .
example.arg: between the ROC islands of Kinmen and Matsu on the one side and the PRC on the other

example.name: args 0, 1 and 3
example.text: Sedges have important effects on many ecosystem processes, including methane flux, because of their transport of oxygen to soils.
